text: Revenue of $27.4B, representing a 6% year-over-year increase.
Net income reached $7.4B, up 11% year-over-year.
EPS was $0.90, an 18% increase year-over-year.
Deposits stood at approximately $2.0T, a 2% year-over-year increase.
CET1 ratio is a preliminary 11.8%, which is well above the regulatory minimum of 10.7%.
Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) are robust at $942B on average.
Return on average common equity was 10.4%.
Return on average tangible common equity was 13.9%.
Return on average assets was 0.89%.
In Consumer Banking, added ~250,000 net new checking accounts, marking 25 consecutive quarters of net growth.
Consumer Banking also added ~1 million credit card accounts and grew Small Business loans by 8% YoY.
Consumer investment assets reached ~$500B, up 9% YoY, with over 4.0 million accounts, up 3%.
Global Wealth & Investment Management added ~7,200 net new relationships and opened ~27,000 new bank accounts.
Client balances in Global Wealth & Investment Management were $4.2T, up 5% YoY, with AUM balances of $1.9T, up 7%.
Total deposits, loans, and investment balances across the wealth spectrum were $5.8T, with $82B in total net wealth client flows since 1Q24.
Global Banking maintained its #3 investment banking fee ranking and gained market share YoY.
In Global Banking, total deposits grew 12% YoY to $592B, and Middle Market average loans grew 6% YoY.
Global Markets reported its 12th consecutive quarter of YoY sales and trading revenue growth, with the highest sales and trading revenue in over a decade.
Global Markets achieved record Equities sales and trading revenue, and record average loan balances of $160B, up 19% YoY, for its 18th consecutive quarter of growth.
Total credit and debit spend was up 4%, with transactions up 2%.
Comparisons are to 1Q24, unless otherwise noted.
Net income of $7.4B; EPS of $0.90; ROE 10.4%, ROTCE 13.9%.
Revenue, net of interest expense, of $27.4B ($27.5B FTE) increased $1.5B, or 6%.
Net interest income (NII) of $14.4B ($14.6B FTE) increased $0.4B, or 3%; up $0.1B, or 1%, vs. 4Q24, despite headwind from two fewer days of interest accrual.
Noninterest income of $12.9B increased $1.1B, or 10%, reflecting growth across all business segments.
Provision for credit losses of $1.5B was flat to 4Q24 and up from $1.3B in 1Q24.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) of $1.5B were flat to 4Q24 and 1Q24.
Noninterest expense of $17.8B increased $0.5B, or 3%.
The balance sheet remained strong, with average deposits of $1.96T increasing by $51B (3%) and average loans and leases of $1.09T increasing by $46B (4%).
CET1 capital of $201B was flat to 4Q24, while the CET1 ratio of 11.8% decreased 11 bps from 4Q24 but remains over 100 bps above the regulatory minimum.
Paid $2.0B in common dividends and repurchased $4.5B of common stock.
The CET1 ratio of 11.8% decreased by 11 bps compared to 4Q24, with CET1 capital remaining flat at $201B.
Standardized Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) increased by $16B to $1.7T.
Book value per share improved 8% from 1Q24 to $36.39, and tangible book value per share improved 9% from 1Q24 to $27.12.
Average Global Liquidity Sources of $942B decreased by $11B compared to 4Q24.
Net interest income (NII) was $14.4B ($14.6B FTE), an increase of $0.1B from 4Q24 and $0.4B from 1Q24.
The increase from 4Q24 was driven by lower deposit costs, higher NII from Global Markets, and asset repricing, partly offset by lower interest rates and fewer days of accrual.
The increase from 1Q24 was due to lower deposit costs and higher NII from Global Markets, which more than offset the impact of lower interest rates and one less day of accrual.
Net interest yield of 1.99% increased 2 bps from 4Q24 and was flat compared to 1Q24.
Blended cash and securities yield stood at 3.23% versus a total deposit rate paid of 1.79%.
Excluding Global Markets, the net interest yield was 2.47%.
A 100 bps parallel shift below the March 31, 2025 forward interest rate curve is estimated to reduce NII by $2.2B over the next 12 months.

1Q25 noninterest expense of $17.8B increased by $1.0B (6%) compared to 4Q24, primarily due to seasonally-elevated payroll taxes, higher litigation costs, revenue-related expenses, and the absence of a $0.3B release of the FDIC special assessment accrual from 4Q24.

Compared to 1Q24, noninterest expense increased by $0.5B (3%), driven by higher revenue-related expenses and investments, partially offset by the absence of the $0.7B 1Q24 FDIC special assessment accrual.
Total net charge-offs of $1.5B in 1Q25 decreased by $14MM from 4Q24. The net charge-off ratio was flat at 0.54%.
Consumer net charge-offs of $1.1B increased by $12MM, driven by seasonally-higher credit card losses, with the credit card loss rate rising to 4.05%.
Commercial net charge-offs of $333MM decreased by $26MM from 4Q24.
Provision for credit losses was $1.5B, flat to 4Q24, including a net reserve build of $28MM.
Allowance for loan and lease losses stood at $13.3B, representing 1.20% of total loans and leases.
Early- and late-stage credit card delinquencies declined from 4Q24.
Nonperforming loans of $6.1B increased by $0.1B from 4Q24.
Commercial reservable criticized utilized exposure of $27.7B increased by $1.2B from 4Q24.
Net income was $2.5B in 1Q25.
Revenue of $10.5B increased 3% from 1Q24, driven by higher net interest income, service charges, and card income.
Provision for credit losses of $1.3B increased $142MM (12%) from 1Q24, driven by credit card net charge-offs.
Noninterest expense of $5.8B increased 6% compared to 1Q24, driven by investments in operations, people, and technology, with an efficiency ratio of 56%.
Average deposits of $948B decreased $5B (1%) from 1Q24, with 58% of deposits in checking accounts.
Average loans and leases of $315B increased $2B (1%) from 1Q24.
Combined credit/debit card spend of $228B increased 4% from 1Q24.
Consumer investment assets of $498B grew $41B (9%) vs. 1Q24, driven by $22B of net client flows.
11.1MM clients were enrolled in Preferred Rewards, up 1% from 1Q24.
78% of households were digitally active, up from 76% in 1Q24.
Net income was $1.0B in 1Q25.
Revenue of $6.0B increased 8% from 1Q24, driven by 15% higher asset management fees from strong AUM flows and higher market levels.
Noninterest expense of $4.7B increased 9% vs. 1Q24, driven by revenue-related incentives and business investments.
Client balances of $4.2T increased 5% from 1Q24, driven by higher market valuations and positive net client flows, including AUM flows of $24B in 1Q25.
Over 62% of clients have a banking relationship.
Average deposits of $286B decreased $11B (4%) from 1Q24, while average loans and leases of $232B increased $14B (6%) from 1Q24.
Added ~7,200 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank in 1Q25.
87% of GWIM households/relationships are digitally active across the enterprise.
Net income was $1.9B in 1Q25.
Revenue of $6.0B was flat vs. 1Q24, as gains from leveraged finance and treasury services were offset by lower net interest income.
Total Corporation investment banking fees (excl. self-led) of $1.5B decreased 3% vs. 1Q24, though market share improved.
Provision for credit losses of $154MM decreased $75MM (33%) from 1Q24, driven by lower commercial real estate office losses.
Noninterest expense of $3.2B increased 6% vs. 1Q24, driven by investments in the business.
Average deposits of $575B increased $49B (9%) from 1Q24.
Average loans and leases of $379B increased $5B (1%) from 1Q24.
Net income was $1.9B, both including and excluding net DVA.
Revenue of $6.6B increased 12% from 1Q24, driven by higher sales and trading revenue and gains related to leveraged finance positions.
Sales and trading revenue of $5.7B increased 11% from 1Q24 (9% excluding net DVA).
FICC revenue increased 8% to $3.5B, driven by strong performance in macro and credit products.
Equities revenue increased 17% to $2.2B, driven by improved trading performance and increased client activity.
Noninterest expense of $3.8B increased 9% vs. 1Q24, driven by higher revenue-related expenses and business investments.
Average VaR was $91MM in 1Q25.
Net loss of $4MM improved from a net loss of $696MM in 1Q24, reflecting the absence of the $0.7B 1Q24 FDIC special assessment accrual.
Total corporate effective tax rate (ETR) for the quarter was approximately 9%.
The tax rate is lower than the combination of the U.S. federal income tax rate and state tax rate, driven primarily by recurring tax credits on investments in renewable energy and affordable housing.
All Other primarily consists of asset and liability management (ALM) activities, liquidating businesses, and certain expenses not otherwise allocated to a business segment.
The loan portfolio is more balanced and has less inherent risk than in earlier periods, with lower concentration in consumer loans and less exposure to unsecured credit and home equity loans.
GWIM loans have more than doubled since 4Q09, and the commercial loan portfolio is more balanced with less concentration in construction loans (91% investment grade or secured).
Stress test results indicate significantly lower expected credit losses in a severe downturn.
The capital base and liquidity have increased significantly since 4Q09, with $93B higher tangible common equity and Global Liquidity Sources more than four times higher.
Approximately 79% of consumer loans are secured, with 36% to GWIM clients.
No. 1 in U.S. Consumer Deposits and No. 1 Small Business Lender.
Certified by J.D. Power for Outstanding Client Satisfaction with Customer Financial Health Support – Banking & Payments.
Merrill Edge Self-Directed is No. 1 in Overall Client Experience for the 7th consecutive year.

Recognized as No. 1 on Forbes' Top Women Wealth Advisors Best-in-State (2025), Barron's Top 1200 Wealth Financial Advisors List (2025), and Financial Planning's 'Top 40 Advisors Under 40' List (2025).
Holds the top position in Managed Personal Trust AUM.
Named Best Private Bank in the U.S. and for Philanthropy and Family Office Services.
Recognized as North America's Most Innovative Bank - 2025 and World's Best Bank for Trade Finance.
Named Best Bank for Cash & Liquidity Management and Best Global Bank for Transaction Banking.
Holds 2025 Share Leader and Best Bank Award for U.S. Corporate Banking & Cash Management.
Maintains relationships with 78% of the Global Fortune 500 and 95% of the U.S. Fortune 1,000.
Recognized as World's Best Bank for Markets, Credit Derivatives House of the Year, and North America CLO House.
Named Best Bank for Foreign Exchange Sales and Trading for Corporates in the U.S.
Awarded Best Non-Traditional Index Provider, No. 1 All-America Trading, and No. 2 Top Global Research Firm.
Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) include cash and high-quality, liquid, unencumbered securities readily available to meet funding requirements.
Reserve build (or release) is calculated by subtracting net charge-offs from the provision for credit losses.
Pretax, pre-provision income (PTPI) is a non-GAAP measure calculated by adjusting pretax income to add back provision for credit losses, used to assess earnings generation ability.
Interest rate sensitivity as of March 31, 2025, reflects the potential pretax impact to forecasted NII over the next 12 months from an instantaneous parallel shock to the forward curve.
Forward-looking statements about NII are based on a baseline forecast considering business growth, ALM positioning, and market-implied interest rate movements.
Revenue for all periods includes net debit valuation adjustments (DVA) on derivatives. Net DVA gains were $19MM for 1Q25.
The VaR model uses a historical simulation approach with a 99% confidence level. Average VaR was $39MM for 1Q25 using a 95% confidence level.
(A) 4Q24 FFIEC Call Reports.
(B) FDIC, 4Q24.
(C) J.D. Power 2024 Financial Health Support Certification is based on exceeding customer experience benchmarks.
(D) StockBrokers.com 2024 Annual Broker Review.
(E) With Intelligence, 2025.
(F) Global Finance, 2025.
(G) Euromoney, 2024.
(H) Treasury Management International, 2025.
(I) Global Finance, 2024.
(J) Coalition Greenwich, 2025.
(M) Extel, 2024.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements which represent the Corporation's current expectations, plans, or forecasts and are not guarantees of future results.
Actual outcomes may differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements due to known and unknown risks, uncertainties, and assumptions.

Uncertainties and risks include, but are not limited to, litigation, regulatory actions, interest rate changes, economic conditions, geopolitical instability, credit losses, and changes in accounting standards.
The Corporation undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking statement to reflect circumstances or events that arise after the date the statement was made.
The information is preliminary and based on data available at the time of the earnings presentation. Bank of America has no duty to update the information.
The presentation may use non-GAAP financial measures to provide clarity on results and trends. Reconciliations can be found in the earnings press release.
Key performance indicators (KPIs) are presented, which management uses to assess consolidated and segment results.
Revenue and net interest income are also viewed on a fully taxable-equivalent (FTE) basis to provide meaningful comparison of interest margin from taxable and tax-exempt sources.
Capital is allocated to business segments using a methodology that considers regulatory capital requirements (Basel 3) and internal risk-based models.
